title: Sheet 4A
publication_title: James Ensor: The Temptation of Saint Anthony
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">The striated formation on the left side of this sheet may represent sedimentary rock, which would link the imagery to new scientific theories gaining currency in Ensor’s time. Charles Lyell’s Principles of Geology (J. Murray, 1830–33) promoted James Hutton’s theory of Uniformitarianism, which in turn influenced Charles Darwin’s ideas on evolution. The rock formation extends into the sheet above (3A), and beside it is a narrow valley full of human heads.

At bottom left, the muzzle of a cannon or spotlight emits a cloud of bugs, snails, spiders, and imaginary creatures that references the rich visual imagery available to Ensor, particularly in the illustrated journals, including La nature, that popularized the latest discoveries in science, biology, and technology (see fig. 1, fig. 2, fig. 3, fig. 4, and fig. 5); ethnographic and anthropological accounts of exploration and discovery; and books explaining Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution, such as Camille Flammarion’s Le monde avant la création de l’homme (The World before the Creation of Man; see fig. 6, fig. 7, and fig. 8). Many of these journals reproduced circular microscopic images or slides; these could also be seen in lectures illustrated by lantern projections that were simultaneously documentary and fantastic (see fig. 9 and fig. 10). Some of the creatures in the drawing—a nude with a dinosaur’s head riding a snail and several larger, horned, devil-like nudes mounted on strange hybrid beasts—are based on the monsters in Jacques Callot’s etching The Temptation of Saint Anthony (fig. 11). The bizarre creatures can also be seen in sheets 4B, 4C, and 5A. The drawing is diminished in some areas and is difficult to read under normal conditions, but details are identifiable with the aid of infrared reflectography (see fig. 12). SMC/KJN

The action in sheets 3A, 3B, 3C, 4A, 4B, and 4C is the source of the engraving Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels (fig. 13). It also indirectly inspired other etchings, such as The Terrible Archer (fig. 14), Cataclysms (fig. 15), Wizards in a Squall (fig. 16), and The Elephant’s Joke (fig. 17). Although Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels is not a direct reproduction of these sheets, the chaotic composition and frightful elements are similar to Saint Anthony’s torments. Many motifs appear in both the print and the drawing, for example, the hot-air balloon, train, sawfish, headless bodies, octopi, insects, elephant, and submarine.

In the drawing the chaos is somewhat contained by the use of schematic registers, but in the etching Ensor dispensed with the organizational structure and allowed the chaos to become overwhelming. Sources of inspiration for the chaos include The Fall of the Rebel Angels by Pieter Bruegel I (fig. 18); versions of the temptation after Pieter Bruegel (fig. 19), by Martin Schongauer (fig. 20), and by Jacques Callot (fig. 11); and battle scenes by the Japanese artists Utagawa Kuniyoshi and Utagawa Kunisada (fig. 21 and fig. 22). These artists provided ideas about overlapping, clashing compositions that Ensor assimilated into his own work. He interpreted these sources to offer viewers a distilled representation that condenses the energy, imagination, anxiety, and virulence of its predecessors. Thanks to this synthesis, the image possesses its own logic and magic that captivates even as it amuses and overwhelms viewers with its detail. ST

fig. 1 Infusoires vus au microscope, published in La nature 2 (1874), p. 240.

fig. 2 Quelques insectes utiles, published in La nature 2 (1874), p. 277.

fig. 3 Jeune larve de Palingenia virgo, published in La nature 4 (1876), p. 45.

fig. 4 Organismes contenus dans le sédiment de l’eau, published in La nature 9 (1881), p. 165.

fig. 5 Développement des crustacés, published in La nature 9 (1881), p. 713.

fig. 6 Protistes, published in Camille Flammarion, Le monde avant la création de l’homme (C. Marpon and E. Flammarion, 1886), p. 158.

fig. 7 Insectes de la période miocène retrouvés à l’état fossile, published in Camille Flammarion, Le monde avant la création de l’homme (C. Marpon and E. Flammarion, 1886), p. 701.

fig. 8 Fragment de craie vu au microscope, published in Camille Flammarion, Le monde avant la création de l’homme (C. Marpon and E. Flammarion, 1886), p. 617.

fig. 9 Poyet. Experience de M le Dr P Begnard, published in La nature 13 (1885), p. 17.

fig. 10 Artist unknown. Printed by Émile Lévy, Paris. Les invisibles, 1883. Color lithograph poster; 130 × 94 cm (5 13/16 × 37 in.). Musée de la Publicité, Paris, 10114. Photo Les Arts Décoratifs, Paris/Laurent Sully Jaulmes.

fig. 11 Jacques Callot (French, 1592–1635). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1635. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; image/sheet (trimmed to platemark): 35.6 × 46.6 cm (14 × 18 3/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Special Account, 1938.1250.

fig. 12 Infrared and natural-light images of sheet 4A of Ensor’s Temptation of Saint Anthony (1887–88). The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006.87.

fig. 13 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Devils Thrashing Angels and Archangels, 1888. Etching from a copper plate, in black with hand-coloring, on buff laid paper; image: 24.8 × 28.7 cm (9 3/4 × 11 5/16 in.); plate: 26.3 × 30.7 cm (10 3/8 × 12 1/8 in.); sheet: 33.3 × 50.8 cm (13 1/8 × 20 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Olivia Shaler Swan Fund Income, 1971.629.

fig. 14 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Terrible Archer, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.7 × 23.9 cm (7 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 28.3 × 39.5 cm (11 1/8 × 15 9/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Fund, 1946.1042.

fig. 15 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Cataclysms, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image: 17.5 × 23.5 cm (6 7/8 × 9 1/4 in.); plate: 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.); sheet: 34 × 47.2 cm (13 3/8 × 18 5/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Joseph Brooks Fair Fund, 1943.1020.

fig. 16 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). Wizards in a Squall, 1888. Etching from a zinc plate, in black, on cream wove paper; image/plate: 17.9 × 23.6 cm (7 1/16 × 9 5/16 in.); sheet: 28.6 × 39.9 cm (11 1/4 × 15 3/4 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Print and Drawing Club Collection, 1946.264.

fig. 17 James Ensor (Belgian, 1860–1949). The Elephant’s Joke, 1888. Etching on paper; 17.9 × 23.8 cm (7 1/16 × 9 3/8 in.). Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, Gift of A. Justin and Lynn M. Sterling, 2005.171.4. © Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

fig. 18 Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Fall of the Rebel Angels, 1562. Oil on panel; 117 × 162 cm (46 × 64 in.). Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels, 584. © Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels/photograph: J. Geleyns/Ro scan.

fig. 19 Pieter van der Heyden (Flemish, c. 1530–after 1572) after Pieter Bruegel I (Flemish, c. 1525–1569). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1556. Engraving on laid paper; 24.3 × 32.5 cm (9 9/16 × 12 13/16 in.). The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 2001.13.3. Image © Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts, USA (photograph by Michael Agee).

fig. 20 Martin Schongauer (German, c. 1450–1491). The Temptation of Saint Anthony, 1470–75. Engraving in black on cream laid paper; sheet: 32 × 23.5 cm (12 5/16 × 9 1/16 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, Jr., 1955.1227.

fig. 21 Utagawa Kuniyoshi (Japanese, 1797–1861). Published by Kogaya Katsugorō (Japanese, c. 1843–1874). The Battle of Dan-no-ura: Suke no Tsubone, Shinchūnagon Taira Tomomori, and Sagami Gorō, c. 1844. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban triptych; 36.7 × 75.3 cm (14 7/16 × 29 5/8 in.). Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.27029-31. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

fig. 22 Utagawa Kunisada (Japanese, 1786–1864). Published by Kawaguchiya Uhei (Japanese, c. 1800–1852). The Killing of Ten (Jūban kiri): Soga Gorō Tokimune and Gosho no Gorōmaru Shigemune, c. 1820. Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper; vertical ōban; 39 × 25.5 cm (15 3/8 × 10 1/16 in.).Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, William Sturgis Bigelow Collection, 11.21579. Photograph © 2014 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
